title: Raw Data: Opioid Prescriptions in the United States â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Comments
As we all know, opioids are overprescribed in the US and thereâ€™s been a big push for many years to cut back. So how are we doing? Are doctors limiting opioids too much? Hereâ€™s some data from a recent JAMA article, â€œTrends and Patterns of Geographic Variation in Opioid Prescribing Practices.â€ First, the total number of opioid prescriptions:
Opioid prescriptions are down 25 percent since their peak in 2012. Thatâ€™s fairly substantial. However, although the average strength of each prescription (measured in the equivalent of milligrams of morphine) has stayed roughly constant, the average length of an opioid prescription has been getting steadily longer. This means that the reduction in prescriptions isnâ€™t quite as large as it seems at first glance:
This is down 16 percent since the 2012 peak. The number of prescriptions for less than three days has declined while the number for more than 30 days has increased. Hereâ€™s the same information by state:
More than half of the decline in opioid prescriptions came in a single year, 2017, and we donâ€™t have figures for 2018 yet. If it shows another steep drop, it will suggest that we really have cut way back on opioid prescriptions.

title: Itâ€™s Friday and Here Are 20 Songs for Your Weekend Soundtrack
content:
TNS/ZUMA Wire
This week: An entire playlist of 20 hand-picked songs!
Why weâ€™re into them: Thereâ€™s a lot of good music out right now. Some you may know, some you may not, and some may deserve a leap of faith. Instead of offering a single great artist or song, this Friday we are giving you 20 greats, each perfectly paired with a particular weekend activity.
â€œEnjoy Your Lifeâ€ â€“ MARINA Perfect forâ€¦ the last essential jolt of energy that you need before crawling into that 4:40 p.m. Friday meeting.
The â€œ Bubblegum Bitch â€ is back and delivering a welcome throwback to what made Marina and the Diamonds so great. Serving us vulnerability with a side of attitude, itâ€™s the track to push you over the finish line and into the weekend.
â€œThe Kingâ€ â€“ Conan Gray Perfect forâ€¦ replacing the intensity of a train ride home with a daydream.
Pop in the headphones and get lost in the crush-heavy world Gray created in â€œThe King.â€ Let yourself be rescued from that person who isnâ€™t respecting your space on the train and drop straight into the loving arms of your crush.
â€œHMLTMâ€ â€“ Novaa Perfect forâ€¦ a sliver of remedial mental solitude before the weekend festivities begins.
With the iconic soft-electro pop/jazz pianist producer Moglii as the support behind her debut album, which is out at the end of April, itâ€™s no wonder this track feels like sunshine on your face. An exploration of her experience recovering from an eating disorder, this song is a comfortable sound perfect for not permitting that snag of existential dread to dominate your headspace.
â€œCon Alturaâ€ â€“ ROSALÃA y J Balvin ft. El Guincho Perfect forâ€¦ pregaming Friday nightâ€™s house party.
ROSALÃA is one of the most exciting artists to break into the mainstream US music scene. Paired with hit-maker J Balvin, this track is the one you need playing as warm up for the weekend.
â€œC.U.D.I (Can U Dig It)â€ â€“ Cosmoâ€™s Midnight Perfect forâ€¦ the house party playlist.
Their beachy music video tells you the kind of vibe this song brings. Itâ€™s a slow and steady track that oozes salty air good vibes. After all, whatâ€™s a real party without good vibes?
â€œMessed Upâ€ â€“ Lizzy Land Perfect forâ€¦ the Saturday morning reconciliation with last nightâ€™s mistakes.
Guilt, regret, and shame are key components to any hangover. In Landâ€™s newest she tackles expectations, for ourselves and those around us. Wallow just a little bit and then get over it.
â€œAnxiousâ€ â€“ Austin Mahone Perfect forâ€¦ a Saturday morning dance party in your undies as your mood shifts while you continue to purge the mistakes from Friday night.
Thereâ€™s nothing unique or original about this song. Itâ€™s a stereotypical Shawn Mendes/Liam Payne/Young-Good-Looking-White-Boy-singing-about girls song. That said, itâ€™s also surprisingly fun and an essential track for a guilty pleasure playlist.
â€œ626 Bedford Avenueâ€ â€“ The Drums Perfect forâ€¦ reminiscing about that boy you kissed at a house party last night and stupidly fell in love with even though it was only one kiss.
This isnâ€™t the only track from The Drums that has graced Mother Jones, but itâ€™s so good it deserves a place here. From their brand new (also fantastic) EP Brutalism, â€œBedfordâ€ is a depressing love song that still, somehow, manages to be joyful.
â€œMixerâ€ â€“ Amber Mark Perfect forâ€¦ smoking a Saturday afternoon joint with a cutie. (If thatâ€™s your thing. If itâ€™s not, this song is perfect for a walk in the sunshine after brunch.)
The energy Amber Marks exudes in this track overflows into the music video and is invigorating. Track after track, she just keeps releasing music that shines.
â€œLove Me Lessâ€ â€“ MAX (feat. Quinn XCII) Perfect forâ€¦ an afternoon of fresh vodka lemonades and a spontaneous potluck in the park.
This new track from pop aficionado MAX has summer written all over it. Dripping in sunshine and soaked in the smell of freshly cut grass, if you dig Bazzi or Diplo, this oneâ€™s for you.
â€œWin You Overâ€ â€“ Whethan and Bearson feat. SOAK Perfect forâ€¦ stabilizing yourself before another night out.
To be expected of the young hit-maker Whethan, comes a track that feels lo-fi yet equally upbeat. With its infectious tone, subtle background chimes, and easy-to-remember chorus, the song never feels stale.
â€œKill This Loveâ€ â€“ BLACKPINK Perfect forâ€¦ the moment you just know you need to dance.
The K-pop megastars are back with an absolutely banging track. Itâ€™s as if Madonnaâ€™s â€œ4 Minutesâ€ and Gwenâ€™s â€œHollaback Girlâ€ had a baby on steroids. Pound a few pints and get down to this Korean pop jam.
â€œGlitter and Bloodâ€ â€“ SuperKnova Perfect forâ€¦ when youâ€™re a bit tipsy from the bar, walking home under the poetic streetlights, and want to feel like youâ€™re in sad (but very cool!) indie movie.
A little bit of Bowie, a little bit of Prince, SuperKnovaâ€™sâ€”real name Ellie Kimâ€”newest track is a must listen for anyone who enjoys an alternative-pop-rock cross genre tune. With her second EP due out this summer, this track only tantalizes us with the proudly trans pop-rock starâ€™s potential.
â€œblack on blackâ€ â€“ Greyson Chance Perfect forâ€¦ sex.
Itâ€™s as if Justin Timberlakeâ€™s voice had been reincarnated into a younger someone else who really knows what to do with it. Itâ€™s sexy, fun, and one of the best tracks off Chanceâ€™s already enjoyable album. (And yes, this is the kid who went viral for singing Lady Gagaâ€™s â€œPaparazziâ€ at his middle school talent show.)
â€œPopstarâ€ â€“ Ryahn Perfect forâ€¦ a Sunday morning of procrastinating while reflecting on the glorious mess of your weekend.
Ryahn dropped this track last year, but itâ€™s just making its way onto our radar due to the tropical getaway that is her new music video. A bit Christina, some Eve, and a sprinkle of Britney, Ryahnâ€™s crafting some gratifying R&B pop.
â€œAnother Loverâ€ â€“ Leland Perfect forâ€¦ sending that special someone a DTR text.
Heâ€™s written for Troye Sivan, Selena Gomez, Charli XCX, Kelsea Ballerini, Betty Who and even Carrie Underwood. He knows how to make a deep, gratifying, singable piece of music, and â€œAnother Loverâ€ is an incredible ensemble addition to his already incredible solo work.
â€œThinkin Bout Youâ€ â€“ Ciara Perfect forâ€¦ afternoon rumination about that crush from the other night.
Ciara is serving some Robyn with a dollop of Janelle MonÃ¡e. Most importantly sheâ€™s serving a new soundâ€”â€Level Upâ€ and â€œDoseâ€ are club bangersâ€”that makes the wait for her new album seem longer than we had thought.
â€œGet StÃ¼pidâ€ â€“ bÃ¼low Perfect forâ€¦ chore time. Hop to it.
Nothing will ever top bÃ¼lowâ€™s debut track â€œ Not A Love Song ,â€ but her newest EP Crystalline is pretty damn close. â€œGet StÃ¼pidâ€ is a chill yet upbeat tune that will keep you energized just enough to knock out your to-do list.
â€œAnywayâ€ â€“ Rebecca Black Perfect forâ€¦ a private concert for your pet as you settle into your now pristine living space.
Never forget . Now that thatâ€™s out of the way, this track is a genuinely enjoyable listen, especially if you ignore the truly awful video. This track is a jump-on-the-trend of the 80â€™s synth-pop resurgence, and a good one at that.
â€œTEMPOâ€ â€“ Lizzo (feat. Missy Elliott) Perfect forâ€¦ the Monday morning pump up as you embark on another week.
Lizzoâ€™s fiery collab with Missy Elliott is the perfect track to put you in the headspace needed to take on the week. Lizzo is the queen of pump up jams , and this song deserves to be the song of the springâ€¦and summer. No competition.
And for your listening pleasure, hereâ€™s an Apple Music and Spotify playlist of these tracks.
Honorable mentions: â€œOld Town Road (feat. Billy Ray Cyrus) [Remix]â€ by Lil Nas X, â€œNoonâ€ by Soft Glas, â€œEmmyâ€ by Sean Grandillo, â€œPeaceâ€ by Alison Wonderland, â€œBad Vibesâ€ by K. Flay.

title: A Death, a Life, and a Border Wall
content:
The border wall between the USA and Mexico in Arizona. Getty Images
In the fall of 1993, Aaron Bobrow-Strain arrived in Tucson, Arizona, near the jagged ridge of the United Statesâ€™ southern border. Dominating the news was debate over the North American Free Trade Agreement, which would be passed by the House that November. As Bobrow-Strain settled into his job at an immigration non-profit, President Bill Clintonâ€™s aggressive new border strategy, known as â€œprevention through deterrence,â€ was ramping up. And in Agua Prieta , a small town just across the borderâ€™s chain-link fence, a little girl named Aida Hernandez was learning to ride a brakeless bicycle and dreaming of living in New York City.
Aida would come of age with the United Statesâ€™ hostile immigration policy, and her life would be indelibly marked by it. Growing up in Agua Prieta, Aida watched residents cross into the US to shop, run errands, and visit family with relative ease. But when, at eight years old, her mother takes her to live in Arizona, her future is rocked by instability; she survives years of domestic violence and becomes a mother at 16. When a misstep leads to deportation without her young son, Aida finds herself back in a Mexican city marked by violence. Her final journey to the border is in an ambulance, where her life rests in the hands of federal agents whose job is to prevent her from entering the country she calls home.
The Death and Life of Aida Hernandez (publish date April 16) weaves the personal narrative of a single immigrant with the complex history of the southern border, where many people used to feel that their culture and identity traversed the border line. For Bobrow-Strain, the violence and terror Aida experienced while trying to make a life on the edge of two nations is a microcosm of an American obsession that has consumed our understanding of our southern neighbors. Aidaâ€™s storyâ€”of border flight, immigration court, for-profit detention, and family separationâ€”is required reading in the age of Trump. â€œThis isnâ€™t just a book about Aida,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s a book written with Aida about a world weâ€™ve created. â€
I spoke to Bobrow-Strain, now a professor of politics at Whitman College, about the way Clintonâ€™s border policy shapes our current-day crisis, and how Aidaâ€™s story exposes the myth of the â€œmodel immigrantâ€ in a country that set her up to fail.
This book wasnâ€™t originally about Aida. In 2014, you went back to Arizona after more than 15 years, to write about the border. But then you were introduced to her . What was that first meeting like?
It was a powerful moment. It was a really hard story to listen to, as readers will see; a brutal story in many ways. But she didnâ€™t ask for my pity. She was really demanding a kind of reckoning with our complicity in creating the laws and policies that made her life almost unlivable. And also, I think, expressing the way in which the act of sheer survival, in a world like the one weâ€™ve made for her, is a form of dignity and worth, as valuable as any affluent personâ€™s achievement.
The other thing I really took out of that first meeting was that she exuded a kind of brio and humor and wit that I think is really important, and I try to capture in the book. Itâ€™s a central piece of many immigrant experiences, but it often gets lost in the â€œtragic immigrantâ€ tales that journalists write.
Her story really encapsulates many recurring themes in our current political dialogue about immigration and the southern border. Iâ€™m thinking about â€œzero toleranceâ€ and family separation, the DREAM Act, and the vilification and criminalization of Mexican immigrants.
There are many twists and turns in her story, and I donâ€™t want to give too much away. But yesâ€”the book takes us in the world of for-profit immigration detention, immigration courts, the asylum processâ€¦Really the intimate workings of our approach to border security. We see the way low-level law enforcement officers make huge, life or death judgements about migrants in streamlined immigration processes that have no possibility of appeal. And we see that things like family separation, the criminalization of people who have been here in the United States and deeply enmeshed in U.S. communities for a very long timeâ€”all of that predates Trump.
One of the key points of the book, when I think about it going out into the world today as opposed to in 2014 when I began writing it, is that itâ€™s really important that the book begins in 1996. Aidaâ€™s childhood and coming-of-age parallels the development of this punitive, aggressive border that weâ€™ve created. I think itâ€™s important to remind liberals that they canâ€™t just get rid of Trump in order to fix the immigration system. Itâ€™s going to require a deeper examination of a 25-year-long, bipartisan obsession with â€œprevention through deterrence,â€ this costly, cruel, and ineffective program.
I was going to ask what it meant to you for the book to be published in this political moment, which you couldnâ€™t have foreseen when you started writing back in 2014. But perhaps Iâ€™m wrong? Did you foresee that this was where we were heading?
I canâ€™t give so much credit to my powers of prediction, but there is an arc to the history of immigration control as a form of racial control in the United States that goes back to the 1790s. In many ways what weâ€™re seeing now is the culmination of a recent process by both Republicans and Democrats. I think, because the book is not just about the current moment, it can help us think more practically and more deeply about how we transform this system that is not working.
One thing that I think was central to my decision to write this book, that has not changed at all, is that I wanted to make a book that expanded the boundaries of empathy and justice to include people whose messy lives donâ€™t fit into our narrow and unrealistic narrative of the â€œgood immigrant/bad immigrantâ€ binary. Itâ€™s really important to recognize how much of our immigration debate hinges on that idea that immigrants have to be perfect, flawless, exceptional achievers to deserve membership in the United States, no matter how deeply they are already a part of U.S. communities. Rosie Mendoza, in the book, says, â€œHumans make mistakes, but immigrants canâ€™t.â€
The book leads us through Aidaâ€™s life, but also navigates a swathe of complex immigration policy and Mexican-US history. Talk to me about your intention for including both the personal narrative and the political context.
Empathy isnâ€™t enough. Personal stories reach people, and I wanted to work in that register of emotional connection. But Iâ€™ve included the history and economics and politics along with the emotional story, because empathy can reduce politics down to feeling sorry for an individual. It lets us off the hook, in some ways, from reckoning with the larger storms of structural injustice and our involvement in that.
For me, as much as I hope this book is an empathetic picture of Aida and her family, I also hope itâ€™s a look in the mirror for more privileged folks, because all of the policies that made her life almost unlivable were created by us, in our name, supposedly to keep us safe.
What were the ethical considerations for using Aidaâ€™s story, particularly given that you aim to show her as a complex and sometimes contradictory person rather than as a purely sympathetic character?
This is something I thought about all the time, as I wrote. Thereâ€™s a long history of exploitative writing on the suffering of poor people, often people of color, written for an affluent audience. For me, that meant there were practical implications for how I did the research, and implications for how I conceived the book itself. And I had to recognize the deficiencies and risks in writing a book about a young, bisexual Latina without much formal education, when Iâ€™m a highly-educated white male.
I tried to be as collaborative as possible, going back to Aida and having her shape the project. Itâ€™s really her hard-won expert knowledge about that world that ultimately drives the book. I gave drafts to other folks who are in the story and listened to their feedback, too. There was a lot of engaging with scholars and activists who are women and people of color, and really learning what they had to stay and listening to their critiques of this kind of writing. Itâ€™s not for me to say whether Iâ€™ve been able to avoid the pitfalls, but thatâ€™s what I set out to do.
You worked with Aida on the book for four years. What was that reporting process like?
I came into this via activism and ethnography, not journalism. I do draw heavily on techniques of journalism, including its commitment to verification. That meant cross-checking Aidaâ€™s accounts of her life with family members and friends, and drawing on school, immigration, court, and medical records. Doing more than a hundred interviews with immigration attorneys, physicians, community leaders, and other people to verify the plausibility of what Aida was saying and to provide broader context. And it also meant being open and transparent in the book about my methods, so readers know what theyâ€™re getting.
But ethnography starts from the idea that our relationships with others are always shaping the way we write about our subjects, and always shaping the way our subjects interact with us. Thereâ€™s no detached, dispassionate research. Thereâ€™s not a sense that, if we can maintain a pure distance, we can get to the objective truth.
And this is not a bad thing. Our emotions and relations are central to how we know the world; theyâ€™re powerful ways of understanding the world. There were always borders between Aida and Iâ€”class, race, gender, ageâ€”and professional boundaries, but we still went through a lot together.
What will people find most surprising about Aidaâ€™s story?
Well, folks who are closely connected to the immigrant community are not going to be surprised by her incredible resilience, her wit, her sense of pride in her ability to get through things by the seat of her pants. And they wonâ€™t be surprised by the way most lives donâ€™t fit into the neat good immigrant/bad immigrant binary.
I think that may be a surprise for readers who are mostly exposed to the mythologies of immigration in the United States, which are about the model immigrant and the idea that you work hard and you get ahead. I think for them, there will probably be some surprises in the story.
Those myths around being a nation of immigrants are often told to reassure native-born U.S. citizens about their value and worth to their country, more than theyâ€™re actually about the lives of real immigrants.
What are your hopes for the book now?
Thereâ€™s been an increasing amount of reporting on the impact of our border system on folks who are crossing the border. But I went into the book thinking about the question: what about the border communities themselves? One thing thatâ€™s really missed today is that thereâ€™s a beautiful richness to life in the borderlands. The creativity and resilience that comes from living oneâ€™s life across international borders. There can be a kind of radical hospitality in borderlands. I think itâ€™s important to recognize that reality.
But also to understand that weâ€™ve set those places up to be sacrificed to this 25-year obsession with hyper-aggressive, expensive enforcement. A manufactured crisis.

title: Kamala Harris Releases 15 Years of Tax Returns â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Jack Kurtz/ZUMA Wire
Sen. Kamala Harris (D-Calif.) released 15 years of her tax returns on Sunday morning, the latest in a steady trickle of Democratic presidential candidates to make the financial disclosure.
According to her returns , Harris and her husband lawyer Douglas Emhoff made nearly $1.9 million together in 2018. Harris reported an income of $157,000 from her position as a US senator; she also earned $320,000 from her book. Emhoffâ€™s income was reported at $1.5 million.
The couple paid about $700,000 in federal taxes.
So far, only five Democratic presidential candidates have released their tax history, a long-held custom going back decades among those running for president. Sen. Bernie Sanders, who has been outspoken in his demands for President Donald Trump to release his tax history, is perhaps the most notable exception, though he has promised to finally to do so tomorrow, on Tax Day.
As for Trump, he continues to reject Democratsâ€™ demands to release his returns. On Sunday, White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders insisted that Congress was â€œ not smart enough â€ to review the presidentâ€™s taxes. House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Richard Neal last week gave the Treasury Department until April 23 to comply with the committeeâ€™s request, before it considers issuing a subpoena for the documents.

title: This Trump Official Mocked Rep. Omarâ€™s Death Threats on Instagram. It Led to More Death Threats.
content:
A post shared by ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ lynnepatton (@lynnepatton) on Apr 13, 2019 at 6:39am PDT
In response, a few of Pattonâ€™s 84,000 followers took the opportunity to comment and some added death threats of their own. One Instagram user said he was surprised that no one had killed the congresswoman yet. Another user said someone should â€œjust do itâ€ rather than just threatening Rep. Omar. Another user, aptly named â€œfathead_mike,â€ said he had no problem with someone killing her. After HUD Secretary Ben Carson appointed Patton to a high-profile position, questions were raised about her qualifications for the job. No such questions arise about her expertise in social media, where her active presence indicates she was likely not unaware of the fact that that posting memes about Rep. Omar could inspire a violent and racist reaction from some of her fans and followers.
Late on Sunday night, Rep. Omar said in a statement that since Trumpâ€™s tweet about her, sheâ€™s seen an increase in the threats against her life. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) has requested increased security for Omar and her family. Nonetheless, one of the most prominent black officials in the Trump administration appears to think itâ€™s not that big a deal. Correction: An earlier version of this article stated that the president took the tweet down. He did not. Looking

title: The Trump Tax Cut Did Bubkes for the Working Class â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Comments
Republicans are unhappy about public perceptions of their tax cut. What happened was simple: they paid lots of attention to the business tax cuts and lots of attention to the tax cuts for this rich, but not so much attenton to the tax cuts for the working and middle classes. The middle classes, of course, pay the bulk of their federal income tax via withholding, and they donâ€™t always notice small weekly changes. What they do notice is their tax refund at the end of the year.
Long story short, the supposed party of the common man didnâ€™t realize that. So when Trumpâ€™s Treasury Department changed the withholding schedules, they withheld less in hopes that people would notice that their paycheck was bigger. They didnâ€™t. But the reduced withholding also meant that tax refunds would be smaller than usual. People did notice that. Thus the public perception that they got screwed by the tax cut. Over at National Review , Ramesh Ponnuru tries to explain this away:
The Times article that Robert VerBruggen highlights below suggests that Democrats have been successful in misinforming the public about how many Americans have gotten a tax cut from the Republicans. But itâ€™s probably not just political spin, or the design of that tax law, that caused people to underestimate the extent of the tax cut. Previous tax cuts have landed the same way. President George W. Bush, in his first term, passed two tax cuts that cut tax bills for everyone who paid income tax and raised taxes on nobody. In 2004, a New York Times/CBS News poll found that fewer than one in five Americans thought they had gotten a tax cut.
So hereâ€™s the thing. As Republicans are fond of pointing out, about half of all Americans donâ€™t pay any federal income tax. Theyâ€™re students, or theyâ€™re poor, or theyâ€™re on disability, etc. Another 20 percent pay so little in taxes that tax cuts are virtually invisible. So right off the bat, somewhere around 70 percent of Americans really didnâ€™t see any benefit from George Bushâ€™s tax cuts. Thatâ€™s not very far off the number in the Times poll.
Roughly the same is true of the 2017 Republican tax cut. The working class saw a tax cut of less than 1 percent on average (second quintile in chart below). That comes to maybe $300, or about $6 per week. Is it any surprise that these taxpayers arenâ€™t exactly brimming over with excitement?
Republicans gave the working class (and the middle class) a temporary and minuscule tax cut while the rich got a big, permanent one. Then, because they donâ€™t really understand the middle class at all, they futzed around with the withholding tables so that lots of people got smaller refunds. Then they wonder why ordinary people arenâ€™t impressed. The answer is simple: itâ€™s because they got close to nothing except a big surprise on tax day. Why would you expect them to be anything but resentful over that? Looking for news you can trust?

title: John Hickenlooper Has a Curious Connection to a Trump Cabinet Secretary
content:
Comments Mother Jones illustration; ZUMA
Former Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooperâ€™s ties to the oil and gas industry run deep, especially when compared to those of other candidates in the unwieldy 2020 Democratic field. In some ways, given that Hickenlooper served two terms in the fifth-largest oil-and-gas-producing state, these connections are not surprising. But what may be less apparent is that his government service also intersected with David Bernhardt, the new secretary of the Interior responsible for opening public lands to industry development. Hickenlooper has also often ended up aligned with Bernhardtâ€™s former law and lobbying firm, Brownstein Hyatt Farber Schreck, on matters regarding fracking, the use of public lands, and support for the oil and gas industry over the interests of consumers.
Any governor of Colorado, no matter what party, would inevitably come into contact with the firm, which represents dozens of clients across the energy sector alone. His own chief of staff, Doug Friednash, came from Brownstein in 2015, only to return to it again before the governorâ€™s tenure ended last year. Hickenlooper has been dubbed â€œFrackenlooperâ€ by critics who claim heâ€™s prioritized major oil and gas development at the expense of citizen activism.
Brownstein is one of the most profitable lobbying firms in the country, and its influence naturally extends into Colorado government as well. According to the Denver alt-weekly Westword , â€œWhen thereâ€™s a hot political issue in Colorado, the Brownstein firm usually has a seat at the tableâ€¦and sometimes more than one.â€
Now, internal emails reveal how the law firm enjoyed a seat at the table very close to the governorâ€™s. They show how Brownstein became a conduit for the relationship between Hickenlooperâ€™s administration and one of its most prominent Colorado clients, the Colorado Oil and Gas Association (COGA), an industry group that led the way in trying to thwart local attempts to restrict fracking. In this matter, pitting local communities against the fossil fuel industry, Bernhardt, who was the chair of Brownsteinâ€™s natural resources division, and Hickenlooperâ€™s administration repeatedly fought on the same side to clear hurdles to drilling.
In 2012 and 2013, two Colorado towns , Longmont and Fort Collins, had placed a moratorium on fracking development. The communities, worried about potential groundwater contamination, argued that municipalities should have the right to reject Coloradoâ€™s fracking expansion, setting up a face-off with the considerably more lax Colorado Oil and Gas Conservation Commission, whose appointments by the governor often include regulators with extensive energy sector connections.
Hickenlooperâ€™s administration sued Longmont and Fort Collins for preempting state law, and, on behalf of COGA, Brownstein sued them in a case that worked its way all the way up to the state Supreme Court. Before becoming Ryan Zinkeâ€™s deputy at the Department of the Interior, Bernhardt was the energy and natural resources chair at the firm with broad responsibilities and a long list of his own clients in the oil sector. In 2016, the state Supreme Court struck down the bans in Longmont and Fort Collins, setting a precedent statewide and providing a big win for Brownstein, Hickenlooper, and COGA.
â€œWe appreciate the Supreme Courtâ€™s guidance on balancing private property rights and local government jurisdiction of oil and gas operations in Colorado,â€ Hickenlooper said in a celebratory statement that struck his usual theme of working with industry, not against it. â€œWeâ€™ll continue to work creatively and energetically with communities and industry to ensure our world-class environment is protected while remaining a place that is welcoming to business and jobs.â€
It is unclear how direct a role Bernhardt played in the industryâ€™s fight as chair of the natural resources division, and the matter doesnâ€™t appear on the listed conflicts of interest in his ethics disclosure. But he was front and center celebrating his firmâ€™s victory in a May 2016 press release issued from the firm: â€œThis case involved precedent-setting issues pertaining to state preemption of oil and gas activities,â€ Bernhardt said in a statement commending his employee, whose â€œknowledge of energy and land use law were on exceptional display in front of the Supreme Court, showing the depth and breadth of our team.â€
A few months after the 2016 state Supreme Court win, environmental activists were gathering signatures for a pair of ballot initiatives, Nos. 75 and 78, that would have given municipalities the power to ban fracking and force fracking operations to be located 2,500 feet from occupied buildings. COGA objected to the efforts and sought a series of meetings, including getting oil and gas executives on the â€œgovernorâ€™s dance cardâ€ to plot a strategy to defeat or at least undermine the initiatives, according to emails obtained through state requests by the watchdog group Documented and shared with Mother Jones.

title: Can a Prosecutor Ever Truly Be Progressive? Ferguson May Be the Ultimate Test Case. - Mother Jones
content:
Comments Credit: Mother Jones; Jeff Roberson/AP
On the night Wesley Bell unseated longtime St. Louis County prosecutor Bob McCulloch, Kayla Reed celebrated a progressive electoral victory and a personal promise fulfilled. Reed has been protesting and organizing in the St. Louis area ever since Darren Wilson, a white cop, shot Michael Brown, a black 18-year-old, in 2014. She remembers the night when McCulloch announced that, after the presentation of evidence, the grand jury had ultimately chosen not to charge Wilson for Brownâ€™s death. She cried. And then she decided , â€œBob McCulloch must be removed from office, no matter the sacrifice or effort it would take.â€
Over the next four years, she worked to make good on that vow. She co-founded Action St. Louis, a black-led activist collective dedicated to political organizing, which helped elect Circuit Attorney Kim Gardner in neighboring St. Louis city in 2016. Two years later, they created viral hashtags and organized fundraising events to help push what is normally a low-turnout local primary held in the dead of summer into a nationally watched race. Gardnerâ€™s election was a major victory. But this was different.
â€œWe celebrated both. But there was more satisfaction from this win because we got to unseat Bob McCulloch,â€ she remembered. â€œIt felt more personal.â€
However, Reedâ€™s joy was not shared by everyone. Several prosecutorsâ€”the very people Bell was expected to leadâ€”were less than excited by the prospect of a new era. It felt personal to them, too. â€œCounty voters will soon regret what they did,â€ an aggrieved assistant county prosecutor of more than 30 years posted on Facebook after the election, giving voice to broader unrest among longtime colleagues of McCulloch. (He was soon fired by Bell.)
During the campaign, McCulloch held firm to his tough-on-crime approach, saying that in his nearly 30 years as a prosecutor, he â€œremoved the most dangerous and violent criminals from our neighborhoods.â€ He proudly emphasized his police roots, often recalling his experience as the son of a cop. McCulloch famously never charged an officer in a shooting, and to questions about the Ferguson protests, McCulloch simply answered that he followed procedure.
Bell made a striking foil in the race. Though he was also the son of a police officer, Bell, a 44-year-old black man, branded himself as a â€œ leader in the streets ,â€ and someone who was unafraid to speak out against racial inequality. He highlighted his experience working with the Department of Justiceâ€”he helped implement recommendations from its report denouncing Fergusonâ€™s racist policing efforts that profited off largely low-income communities of color by overwhelming them with fees for petty misdemeanors like traffic violations . Bell heavily criticized the decision not to prosecute Wilson, using it as an example of why police and prosecutors should remain â€œseparate and independent.â€ His campaign broadcast a series of ambitious reforms: a pledge to prioritize serious crime over petty misdemeanors, an end to the death penalty, and a requirement for police oversight.
To his supporters, Bellâ€™s proposals are a model for criminal justice reform, joining those of prosecutors like Larry Krasner in Philadelphia, Rachael Rollins in Suffolk County, Massachusetts, and Mark Gonzalez in Nueces County, Texas, who have helped popularize the term â€œprogressive prosecutor.â€ The classification, while vague, carries enough weight now that there is debate about who qualifies for the term. Notably, since California Sen. Kamala Harris announced her campaign for president, the debate has reached mainstream national attention. Sheâ€™s proudly dubbed herself a progressive prosecutor, referring to her roles as former San Francisco district attorney and then California attorney general, but critics are quick to point to her record of prosecuting sex workers and targeting people for truancy as evidence to the contrary.
Bell has a particularly fine line to walk in his new position. As a prosecutor in a birthplace of the Black Lives Matter movement, heâ€™s balancing significant pressure from the activists who helped elect him while he works within the system that inspired their anger in the first place. Bell says he wears his label of progressive prosecutor â€œas a badge of honor,â€ but he also admits that it can weigh him down. â€œThatâ€™s where the conversation gets muddled and the tendency is to pick a side,â€ he tells Mother Jones .
According to David Alan Sklansky , a Stanford law professor focusing on criminal procedure, Bell will continue to feel the burden that comes with such an ill-defined label as he gets further into his tenure. â€œThe record of any prosecutor is going to be mixed,â€ Sklansky says. â€œAnd because thereâ€™s some ambiguity about what parts of being a progressive prosecutor are most important, thereâ€™s going to be some ambiguity about whether somebody whoâ€™s been in office and has done some things progressiveâ€¦and not made progress on some other [progressive] issues, should be given more years.â€
For his part, Bell says he isnâ€™t so concerned about labelsâ€”he only cares about implementing policy that works.
Bell has been ruminating on concrete policy solutions for a racist criminal justice system for a long time; he is optimistic about the potential for change, yet realistic about the immeasurable challenges before him. â€œYou are never truly free if your brother is in chains,â€ he said in a recent banquet speech at the University of Missouri School of Law, calling the criminal justice system one of the â€œgreatest ills of our society.â€ He ended his address on a hopeful note: â€œIt is possible to change the laws of the land.â€
His aspirations for a better future paired with his matter-of-fact way of speaking about inequality is in part what earned Bell a devoted political following after the Ferguson protests in 2014. The following year, he ran for City Council in the third ward, mixing policy rhetoric with clear proposals. â€œWhat Iâ€™ve been screaming from the hills for years isâ€¦community-oriented policing,â€ he told an interviewer during that race.
After Bell won in a landslide with nearly 70 percent of the vote, he helped set up the North County Police Cooperative in that image. The initiative was both a progressive and logistical fixâ€”it emphasized community partnership and consolidated multiple local police departments across St. Louis County into a single unit. The new police force calls itself a â€œpositive alternative to the status quoâ€ and says citizens should expect cops to coach sports teams, shake hands, and set up movie nights in addition to their patrol work.
As a politician, Bell was praised for seeing the Ferguson protests for what they wereâ€”a major opportunity for reform and a turning point in a long tradition of racism and police brutality. â€œThese events will be in our kidsâ€™ history books,â€ he said . â€œWe have an opportunity here to effectuate sustainable change and progress. We have the eyes of the world watching.â€
After three years as a Ferguson city councilman, Bell decided to run for prosecutor. â€œThereâ€™s a real need for criminal justice reform in not only St. Louis County, but around the country,â€ he told the New York Times shortly after he announced plans to run. â€œFor years, prosecutor/D.A. races have just kind of run under the radar. But now people are much more aware of the impact of this office, and thatâ€™s a good thing.â€ Bell criticized McCulloch in the local press for his reluctance to stick his neck out to change policing after Ferguson. â€œIt would have been nice to have some support from that office,â€ he said . â€œYouâ€™re talking about one of the most tenured elected officials in our state not having any footprint on much-needed reforms in the area that heâ€™s representing.â€ He also condemned McCullochâ€™s decision to handle the Michael Brown case personally, saying that he should have recused himself. â€œIt was completely inappropriate for him to handle that case.â€
But by the time Bell was elected in November, he had already seen up close how a progressive prosecutorâ€™s honeymoon could quickly sour. Kim Gardner was elected the city of St. Louisâ€™ circuit attorney in 2016â€”the first African-American to hold that office. (The city of St. Louis, where Gardner was elected, is separate from St. Louis County, where Bell is positioned and where Ferguson is located.) She too was elected on a reform agenda two years after Brownâ€™s death. â€œKim was just slightly before the hype,â€ Reed says. â€œ[She] was really one of the first elected under this idea of a progressive prosecutor.â€
Indeed, Gardner drew the support of activists like Reed and members of Action St. Louis, who endorsed her campaign after holding forums for the candidates. The tone of Bellâ€™s campaign was quite similar to that of Gardnerâ€™s. Both were vocal about issues of racism and police misconduct. â€œIâ€™m a peopleâ€™s champ,â€ Gardner told reporters after winning the Democratic primary on a platform of ending mass incarceration.
She took office quietly in January 2017. To the hopeful activists who had helped elect her, it was unclear if she was head-down working toward reform or she simply wasnâ€™t doing anything at all. She said sheâ€™d been working mostly behind the scenes on low-level felony negotiations. But months later, the Riverfront Times published a report that quoted frustrated prosecutors who said they had waited around for Gardner to introduce her agenda of reform after she took office.
â€œWhen Kim is referred to as a progressive prosecutor it makes me cringe,â€ a prosecutor told the paper. â€œHer approach has been, when in doubt, lock them up.â€
Gardner often puts the difficulty of her position in the context of the â€œpost-Fergusonâ€ eraâ€”in an interview with the Riverfront Times , she invoked the qualifier multiple times. She has been scrutinized for her insistence on taking a carjacking case to trial in which both the FBI and the prosecutor on the case expressed doubts about the defendantâ€™s guilt. The defendant was acquitted in the end, but not before he spent six months in jail awaiting trial. And then there was the case involving police officer Jason Stockley, who was charged with murdering Anthony Lamar Smith, a 24-year-old African American man, after a 2011 car chase. The case was a holdover from the previous administration, but it was tried under Gardnerâ€™s oversight. Stockley was found not guilty of murder, and protests erupted as a result.
Jeff Roorda, head of the St. Louis Police Officers Association, and his union clashed first with Gardner. Last August, the Post-Dispatch broke a story that Gardner had a list of 28 officers on the police force she refused to take cases from, citing past misconduct. Roorda hit back by telling the Riverfront Times that Gardner â€œcompletely ruinedâ€ the relationship between the cops and the prosecutorâ€™s office, and at Christmastime, he included an image of Gardner photoshopped to look like the Grinch in the union newsletter, alongside insults in rhyme. At a panel in January, Bell and Gardner both went on record with their grievances against the union. Gardner called it â€œone of the most aggressive unions in the country.â€
Bell hopes to avoid some of these pitfalls by keeping the channels of communications open with new prosecutors and the public. â€œThere are some core beliefs that I wonâ€™t budge on, but the implementation of those beliefs, those reformsâ€”we want the institutional knowledge, we want input,â€ he said. â€œI donâ€™t think itâ€™s a matter of people being diametrically opposed.â€
Even so, the tensions between Bell and law enforcement began to escalate before Bell was sworn in. In December, two weeks before he was set to officially take office, the St. Louis County prosecutorial staff joined the St. Louis Police Officers Association, Roordaâ€™s police union in neighboring St. Louis city. It was a bold, unprecedented move: Joining the police officersâ€™ union meant a potential conflict of interest if a county prosecutor needed to look into a city officer. Bell, for his part, insists that any situation in which prosecutors are allied with police is an inherent conflict of interest, given the nature of their jobs, which was a key area of outrage after Brown was killed. The discretion given to a prosecutor is compromised if theyâ€™re obviously pro-police. And perhaps more importantly, it signaled that prosecutors in Bellâ€™s office were not open to the change he promised. The Washington Post called it â€œa direct attackâ€ on Bell and his promised reforms.
In theory, if there were a situation in which a prosecutor from the county needed to look into a police officer from the city, the job could be kicked to the attorney generalâ€™s office. But the conflict of interest concerns go beyond that, says Kate Levine , a professor at St. Johnâ€™s University who has written about the relationship of prosecutors and police. â€œProsecutors exercise so much power in the criminal justice system,â€ she says, â€œthey have total discretion about when and whether to bring charges.â€ The alliance aimed to send a message to Bellâ€”that his ideas about reform and social justice were not welcomeâ€”but it also further violated the trust of a community that was still reeling from Brownâ€™s death and the decision not to prosecute Wilson.
â€œWhen St. Louis [County] folks donâ€™t prosecute a police officerâ€”they may have a good reason for not doing itâ€”but [now] itâ€™s even uglier,â€ she told Mother Jones . â€œTheir appearance of impartiality is pretty much all they have to recommend to the people who they allegedly represent that they have their interests in mind.â€
The controversial alliance reminds Reed of the way officers wore bracelets supporting Darren Wilson after Michael Brownâ€™s death. â€œThey felt attacked by people asking for something different,â€ she said. â€œWhile 100,000 people voted for change, a few people can stop or can try to challenge that.â€
At the very least, the timing was â€œodd,â€ wrote local columnist Tony Messenger. There was no reason to rush unionization right before Bell took office. It could have been because of a desire to move swiftly, mused Messenger, â€œor maybe itâ€™s just Bell, who promises change.â€
Union leaders maintain that this isnâ€™t unusual or a conflict of interest, because the county and city are independent of each other. Roorda says that claims that his union is trying to curtail Bellâ€™s reform efforts are â€œcomplete nonsense.â€ Any frustration over unionization, he says, is â€œbecause [Bellâ€™s] reforms are falling flat on their face and theyâ€™re lashing out looking for someone to blame.â€ (Roorda is also the author of Ferghanistan: The War on Police . He donated a portion of the proceeds from his book to Wilson.)
He also takes Bellâ€™s criticisms of the unionization as a personal attack on his officers. â€œThe policemen are not the system,â€ Roorda says. â€œAnd people get the two confused all the time. My cops, I think universally believe that itâ€™s their job to deliver criminals to the doorstep of the prosecutorâ€™s office. If the prosecutor doesnâ€™t do their job, then thatâ€™s up to them.â€
Bell insists that most prosecutors are on board with his reforms, and heâ€™s consulting with his employees as he speedily moves through his list of campaign promises. His first day on the job, Bell instructed staff in an interim memo that cash bail for misdemeanors should be an exception rather than the rule, to not â€œoverchargeâ€ on felonies, and to share documents with defense counsel. (Similar pre-trial discovery rules are being championed as a major progressive victory in New York.) On his second day, he fired the prosecutor who presented evidence to the grand jury in the Michael Brown case, which resulted in Wilsonâ€™s freedom. Bell announced a couple of weeks later that his office wonâ€™t prosecute most low-level marijuana possession cases, and similarly that prosecutors will not pursue child support cases criminally, instead opting to handle such disputes in civil court . In a high-profile case involving charges of sexual assault and murder, he refused to seek the death penalty .
All of these edicts were met with union pushback, but the group was particularly incensed over the change to child support cases. A union lobbyist tweeted that supporters of the policy are â€œdead beat parents.â€ Soon after, there was legislative pushback: Jim Murphy, a Republican state representative, introduced a bill in January to empower the state attorney general to prosecute cases that the district attorney passes on.
â€œThereâ€™s really a break in this two or three-decade-long law-and-order position,â€ Reed said. The speed of Bellâ€™s efforts has pushed prosecutors and police to fundamentally change how they see themselves within the system and unlearn long-established processes. Reed thinks Bell has done a good job clearly communicating with the public while moving internally on reforms. Sheâ€™s happy with his progress so far, and she hopes Bell continues to ramp up the fight against mass incarceration, a key issue for Action St. Louis, which is currently working to reform conditions at the St. Louis city jail. Still, such a quick succession of changes, Sklansky says, can cause anxiety because â€œthere are entrenched parts of the criminal justice system that are used to doing things the way that theyâ€™ve done them.â€
Take the reform that Bell outlined in his day-one policies to give more evidence to the defense before trial. Line-level prosecutors, the same who unionized, will be the ones to do that. Police will have to produce that evidence. â€œA lot of discretion and prosecution work is necessarily diffused,â€ says Sklansky. People will have to relearn their own jobs. Ray Hartmann, the founder of the Riverfront Times , put it like this: â€œIf Bell is a reformer, Roorda and his ilk are the reformees.â€
Miriam Krinsky, executive director of Fair and Just Prosecution, which brings together reform-minded prosecutors across the country, said those kinds of growing pains are necessary. â€œThere has yet to be a full recognition within [some] offices that the criminal justice system has tried to do too muchâ€”that it fills the space that, instead, public health or mental health or social services should be filling,â€ she said. â€œI think there is a need for a reset button in many of the offices to be hit.â€
But that doesnâ€™t mean it wonâ€™t cause agitation.
â€œA prosecutorâ€™s job is to enforce the laws. The courts interpret them. And we [the Legislature] make them. If he wants to change the law, he ran for the wrong office,â€ Murphy told Mother Jones . â€œHe can have a case-by-case discretion, but certainly not discretion to just become the king.â€
Bell remains unfazed.
â€œWeâ€™re still going to implement the reforms and policies that St. Louis County voters overwhelmingly voted for,â€ he said.
And above all, for all the confusion about how to define who is and isnâ€™t a truly â€œprogressive prosecutor,â€ Bell says heâ€™s looking for policies â€œthat actually workâ€”thatâ€™s the litmus test.â€
â€œIt is on to prosecutors like myself, who are considered progressive, to push,â€ he said. â€œBut also, I hope other prosecutors who may not fall under that line of thinking out there start to do their homework and do their research. Because these policies work.â€ Looking for news you can trust?

title: The Russia Probe Wasnâ€™t the Only Time Trump Interfered With the Justice Department â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Jeff Sessions on October 25, 2018 in Washington. Mark Wilson/Getty Images
Special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s report, due for release on Thursday, is expected to detail President Donald Trumpâ€™s efforts to interfere with FBI investigations into contacts between his 2016 campaign and Russia. In particular, the report may discuss Trumpâ€™s attempt to convince former Attorney General Jeff Sessions to undo his decision to recuse himself from overseeing the Russia matter.
Sessions rebuffed Trumpâ€™s demand that he take control of the probeâ€”a choice that ultimately paved the way for Muellerâ€™s appointment and helped create a major rift between the president and his first attorney general. But as a lawsuit quietly winding its way through the courts makes clear, that wasnâ€™t the end of the story.
â€œIt looks a lot like an attorney general trying to curry favor with an out-of-control boss.â€ Sessionsâ€™ initial recusal announcement was broad: He promised to avoid involvement in investigations into any matters relating to the 2016 presidential campaign. But as Mother Jones has reported, he repeatedly violated that pledge during his time in office. Indeed, after months by public badgering by Trump, Sessions complied with his bossâ€™ demand that the Justice Department investigate Hillary Clinton. In November 2017, Sessions instructed the US Attorney for Utah, John Huber, to look into several issues related to Trumpâ€™s 2016 opponent.
While it has been overshadowed by Trumpâ€™s fury at the Mueller probe, critics say Sessionsâ€™ instructions to Huber were an alarming example of Trump successfully pressuring the nationâ€™s top law enforcement officer into launching an investigation of a political opponent.
â€œIt looks a lot like an attorney general trying to curry favor with an out-of-control boss,â€ Austin Evers, executive director of American Oversight, a liberal government watchdog group, told Mother Jones . â€œThe Department of Justice opened an undefined investigation of Hillary Clinton based on the political demands of Congress and the president, not the existence of new evidence.â€
Sessionsâ€™ order to Huber is at the center of a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit American Oversight is pursuing in federal court in Washington. The organization charges that senior Justice Department officials, including Huber and former Acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker, acted in â€œbad faithâ€ in the litigation by denying the existence of written communications conveying Sessionsâ€™ instructions to Huber. On Tuesday, the group asked a judge to allow discovery, rare in FOIA cases, so that it can seek additional information it says the department might be concealing.
A spokeswoman for Huber referred comments to departmentâ€™s national spokeswoman, who did not comment by the time of publication.
As Muellerâ€™s investigation heated up in July 2017, Trump began regularly blasting Sessions in tweets and other statements , attacking him over his Russia recusal decision and urging him to investigate Clinton. Trump, who said as a candidate that Clinton would â€œbe in jailâ€ if he were president, called for the Justice Department to probe Clintonâ€™s use of a private email server while she was Secretary of State, despite the departmentâ€™s high-profile completion of its investigation into the matter in 2016. Trump also wanted prosecutors to look into what he said were Clintonâ€™s own ties to Russia.
â€œSo many people are asking why isnâ€™t the A.G. or Special Council looking at the many Hillary Clinton or Comey crimes,â€ Trump tweeted on July 22, 2018. Two days later, he wrote , â€œSo why arenâ€™t the Committees and investigators, and of course our beleaguered A.G., looking into Crooked Hillarys crimes & Russia relations?â€
Trumpâ€™s push drew backing from Capitol Hill, where various senior Republicans joined in calls for Sessions to name a special counsel to investigate Clintonâ€™s role as Secretary of State in authorizing the sale of Uranium One, a Canadian company with mining operations in the United States, as well as other matters. Sessions declined to appoint a new special counsel, but in a November 13, 2017, letter to then-House Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte (R-Va.), Assistant Attorney General Stephen Boyd wrote that Sessions had â€œdirected senior federal prosecutors to evaluateâ€ the lawmakersâ€™ request.
Following reports about Boydâ€™s letter, American Oversight filed FOIA requests seeking more information on what exactly Sessions had ordered. When the group didnâ€™t receive a response, it sued the Justice Department. In November 2018, as part of an effort to have the suit thrown out, the DOJ filed a declaration by Vanessa Brinkmann, a senior lawyer in the departmentâ€™s office of information policy. Brinkmannâ€™s sworn statement said that another DOJ official, a counselor to Sessions, had informed her that Huber and Whitakerâ€”who at the time was Sessionsâ€™ chief of staffâ€”said that Sessions had issued â€œno written guidance or directives to Mr. Huberâ€ with respect to investigating Clinton. The instructions were only issued orally, the department claimed. This meant that the Justice Department did not have to cough up a written record of Sessions ordering a probe of Clinton.
â€œI donâ€™t think weâ€™re dealing with recalcitrance here. I think weâ€™re dealing with dishonesty.â€ But on March 8, 2019, Brinkmann sent American Oversight a â€œsupplemental responseâ€ containing an email from Whitaker to Huber with a letter from Sessions attached. â€œI have requested that you review the matters referencedâ€ in Boydâ€™s November 2017 letter to Goodlatte, Sessionsâ€™ wrote. Sessions asked Huber to recommend â€œwhether any matters not currently under investigation warrants the opening of an investigation, whether any matters currently under investigation require further resources or further investigation, and whether any matters would merit the appointment of a Special Counsel.â€ Brinkmannâ€™s letter did not explain how the department found a letter she previously claimed did not exist.
Evers said DOJâ€™s reversal offers reason for the judge in the FOIA case to allow discovery based on a finding that the department acted in â€œbad faithâ€ in its response. â€œWe have that in spades here,â€ Evers said. â€œI donâ€™t think weâ€™re dealing with recalcitrance here. I think weâ€™re dealing with dishonesty.â€
Sessions publicly revealed Huberâ€™s probe in a March 2018 letter to lawmakers, months after requesting it. He claimed at the time that he received â€œregular updates from Mr. Huber.â€ But the department has revealed nothing about where the investigation has led.
Huberâ€™s is not the only Justice Department probe into matters that Trump and his allies have clamored to have investigated. The DOJâ€™s inspector general is looking into the origins of the FBIâ€™s Russia investigation. Testifying before the House last week, Attorney General William Barr said he had launched a separate probe to â€œget my arms around all the aspectsâ€ of the bureauâ€™s counterintelligence investigation. Barr said he wants to determine whether the FBI had sufficient legal justification for investigating the Trump campaign.
But Barr drew far more attention for stating that he believed â€œspying did occurâ€ in the Russia case. His words drew denunciations from Democrats but pleased the president. â€œThese were crimes committed by Crooked Hillary, the DNC, Dirty Cops and others! INVESTIGATE THE INVESTIGATORS!â€ Trump tweeted .

title: Mexicoâ€™s Monarch Butterflies Are in Grave Danger. Scientists Are Moving an Entire Forest to Save Them.
content:
Comments Monarch butterflies on a rock at the El Capulin Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve in Macheros, Mexico. Richard Ellis/ZUMA
Welcome to Recharge, a weekly newsletter full of stories that will energize your inner hellraiser. See more editions and sign up here .
Tree by tree, Mexican scientists are planting the first stages of a new forest in the mountains of the countryâ€™s central Michoacan state. Theyâ€™re taking saplings from oyamel fir trees further down the mountain and creating a new home for them higher up. Three and a half years ago, the first batch of transplanted trees were each seven inches tall. Now, thousands of saplings have grown, some up to four feet tall.
These trees are home to millions of eastern monarch butterflies who migrate there every winter, and in moving the forest, scientists are hoping theyâ€™ll be able to save the species and their habitat. Worldwide, the monarchsâ€™ habitats have become increasingly endangered by herbicides, logging, and the storms and warming temperatures associated with climate change. The new forest, which researchers hope to replicate on nearby mountaintops, would replace lower-altitude forests that are getting too warm for butterfly hibernation. The trees create a cooler microclimate for the butterflies and protect them from chilly winter rains. The experiment is a form of â€œassisted migrationâ€ that is also happening with other plant and animal species in places such as Canada and in parts of the United States .
â€œItâ€™s an idea that may sound radical,â€ forest geneticist Cuauhtemoc Saenz-Romero tells the Los Angeles Times . â€œBut by the end of the century it may be absolutely needed.â€
Mexican researchers and farmers are doing the transplanting, including Francisco Ramirez Cruz. A local 75-year-old farmer, he is helping to grow the saplings in a greenhouse and transplant them up the mountain. He says preserving the butterfliesâ€™ habitat will also help protect the tourism and timber on which many of his neighbors depend.
â€œIn the early days, we didnâ€™t know where they came from,â€ he says of the fluttering wonders. â€œBut we have always been so happy to see them.â€
Here are some other Recharge stories to get you through the week. Short story with your commute? Thanks to new vending machines at a British rail station, commuters have been offered a mental treat: A choice between one-, three-, and five-minute short stories, printed out for the trip. Riders seem to enjoy the three free vending machines, which were installed earlier this month at Canary Wharf in London, and the effort helps people get off their phonesâ€”for a bit. â€œEvery single day,â€ says commuter Paresh Raichura, â€œIâ€™m on the lookout for something new to read.â€ ( The Guardian ) An inspiring advance. Computer scientist Katie Bouman became an internet star last week when a photo of her in front of the first image of a black hole went viral. Trolls quickly descended, denigrating her effort and wrongly crediting a male colleague with the bulk of the discovery. MIT clarified that her contributions were significant to the project, inspiring the teamâ€™s methods to build the final image. Boumanâ€™s work was part of a 200-member team effort, and in a Facebook post she emphasized: â€œNo one algorithm or person made this image.â€ What canâ€™t be denied is the infectious joy that Bouman brought to the moment, as seen in this video from Nature . ( NBC News ) The world rallies for Notre Dame. After the devastating fire in Paris this week, global leaders sang praises and offered prayers. Donors have pledged hundreds of millions of dollars to help rebuild. And when the fire topped its iconic spire and destroyed much of its roof, students and others took to the streets Monday night to serenade the famous cathedral, whose altar and famous bell tower still stood. â€œHonestly, itâ€™s more moving than I could describe,â€ tweeted one visitor, who shared a video of the singing procession . Franceâ€™s US ambassador thanked Americans for their support and added: â€œAll together, weâ€™ll rebuild #NotreDame for the coming millennium.â€ ( CNN ) Get the good news you need right now.

title: The Trump Files: Donald and Melaniaâ€™s Creepy, Sex-Filled Interview With Howard Stern â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Mother Jones illustration; Shutterstock
If you think Donald Trump is a headache for GOP chairman Reince Priebus, who frequently has to clean up after Trumpâ€™s inflammatory comments, just imagine what former Reform Party chairman Russ Verney had to go through. Verney led the party during the 2000 election, when Donald Trump briefly jumped into the race for the Reform nomination for president. But that didnâ€™t stop Candidate Trump from going on Howard Sternâ€™s radio show and putting his then-girlfriend and now-wife Melania on air with the host for a bizarre, creepy, and totally misogynistic interview about life and sex with Trump.
When Trump called in to Sternâ€™s show on November 9, 1999, the conversation turned to Melania (â€œa potential first lady,â€ Trump said) and her looks. â€œLet me talk to that broad in your bed,â€ Stern demanded. So Trump summoned Melania, who was apparently scantily clad and conveniently sitting nearby, to come to the phone. With Stern oozing his creepiest charm, things rapidly got weird.
After demanding that Melania â€œput on your hottest outfitâ€ for a Stern-Trump night on the town, Stern asked Melania what she was wearing right then. â€œUh, not much,â€ she replied.
Stern pressed on: â€œAre you naked? Are you nude?â€ Melania laughed. â€œAlmost,â€ she said.
â€œAhhh, Iâ€™ve got my pants off already,â€ Stern groaned.
Dropping his voice, Stern asked about how often Melania and Trump had sex and how good it was. â€œWe have a great, great time,â€ she said, claiming that she and Donald did the deed â€œeven moreâ€ than daily. â€œI can tell you need love,â€ Stern told her. Other topics of the interview included whether Melania stole cash from Trumpâ€™s wallet, what she wore to the beach, and her â€œvery nice chest for a model.â€
Trump apparently had no problems with Sternâ€™s racy questioning of his then girlfriend. â€œOh man, sheâ€™s naked there, isnâ€™t she?â€ Stern asked when Trump got back on the phone. â€œShe is actually naked,â€ Trump said. â€œItâ€™s a thing of beauty.â€
In a version of the interview clipped by BuzzFeed News , Stern begged Trump to have sex with Melania on air to boost his ratings. â€œWouldnâ€™t that be nice?â€ Trump replied. Someone in Sternâ€™s studio then launched into a crude impression of Melania having sex with Trump. â€œPlease, Donald, donâ€™t put it there!â€ he cried in a fake accent as Sternâ€™s crewâ€”and Trumpâ€”collapsed into laughter. The New York Post also reported that, during the interview, Trump told Stern he frequently â€œmentallyâ€ felt up Melania in public.
But the sex- and harassment-filled radio appearance didnâ€™t exactly strike Trump as a bad move. â€œIs this your average interview, Robin, for a presidential candidate?â€ he proudly asked Sternâ€™s co-host before weighing on the role of hotness in the Monica Lewinsky scandal. â€œThere are those that say that if President Clinton was caught with a supermodel, he would have been everyoneâ€™s hero. Now, of course, I would never say a thing like that, but there are those that say that.â€
â€œPresident Trump will be a reality,â€ Stern said as Trump signed off. â€œThank you, Mr. President.â€
Verney, the Reform Party chairman, was nonplussed by the sexually charged Stern interview. â€œThe very first principle of the Reform Party is to set the highest ethical standards for the White House and Congress,â€ he told the Post , â€œnot the most base, crass attempt to appeal to the lowest common denominator. title: Americans Are Really Afraid of a Looming World War - Mother Jones
content:
Hereâ€™s another interesting GSS chart for you. I still havenâ€™t extracted the data I went there for, but Iâ€™ll get to it eventually. In the meantime, check this out:
There are several surprising things here: First, that the numbers in general are so high. Half the population expects us to be in a world war sometime in the next decade? Wow. Second, that the number spiked after 9/11 and stayed high. More people today expect a world war than they did during the actual Cold War. Third, that responses have stayed so consistent even though we havenâ€™t been in a world war . Youâ€™d think that after years and years of this prediction not coming true, people would start to figure that a world war was unlikely. But no.
I donâ€™t know what to make of this. Either Americans are way more pessimistic than I thought, or else they have a very different idea of what a â€œworld warâ€ is than I do.
POSTSCRIPT: Itâ€™s worth noting that this fear of a world war changes a little bit if you break things out by demographic group, but not by much. Men and women, blacks and whites, Democrats and Republicans, young and oldâ€”they all have roughly the same fear that weâ€™ll be in a world war sometime soon. Looking for news you can trust?

title: The Mueller Report Was Just Released. Read It Here. â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Mother Jones; J. Scott Applewhite/AP; Getty
The Justice Department on Thursday released a redacted copy of special counsel Robert Muellerâ€™s report, revealing some results of the nearly two-year investigation into the Trump campaignâ€™s contacts with Russia.
Mueller completed his report last month, but the release was delayed while the Justice Department redacted what Attorney General William Barr said were several types of sensitive information in the report. In a March 24 letter to Congress, Barr summarized what he called the â€œprincipal conclusionsâ€ of the nearly 400-page report. Barr Quote: : d part of a sentence in the report in which Mueller concluded that the â€œinvestigation did not establish that members of the Trump Campaign conspired or coordinated with the Russian government in its election interference activities.â€ Barr made similar comments in a press conference Thursday morning before the release of the redacted report.
Barr also said in his March letter that Mueller found evidence â€œon both sides of the questionâ€ of whether Trump obstructed justice during investigations into the matter and that Mueller noted specifically that the report did not exonerate Trump of obstruction.
Barr said that due to Muellerâ€™s failure to reach a conclusion on obstruction, Barr and Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein considered the allegations and concluded that Trump did not commit â€œan obstruction of justice offense.â€ Trump and his defenders claimed that Barrâ€™s letter cleared Trump of wrongdoing. â€œNo Collusion, No Obstruction, Complete and Total EXONERATION,â€ Trump tweeted shortly after the letterâ€™s release. The White House, its congressional allies, and pro-Trump pundits also launched a campaign to vilify political opponents who had exposed or criticized Trumpâ€™s ties to Russia.
Even before the release of the redacted report, some members of Muellerâ€™s team reportedly told associates that Barr had failed to accurately represent their findings. Some of Muellerâ€™s investigators have said they found â€œalarming and significantâ€ information on Trumpâ€™s efforts to obstruct investigations into his conduct, the Washington Post reported . Mueller team members were also reportedly irked by Barrâ€™s refusal to release summaries they had prepared for different sections of the report. Barr instead offered his own public description that, critics said, seemed to be intended to minimize any negative findings in the report.
Democrats in Congress have demanded that Barr turn over a complete copy of the report, without redactions. While Barr has claimed he is prohibited from sharing information protected under grand jury secrecy rules, Democrats say Barr could avoid that issue by getting a court order allowing the materialâ€™s disclosure. They have also asked Barr to share evidence gathered by Mueller in support of the report. The release of the redacted report is unlikely to end the dispute. House Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler (D-N.Y.) has said he may use subpoena authority in a bid to force Barr to turn over more information, setting up a potential court battle.
You can read the redacted version of Muellerâ€™s report below.

title: Mueller â€œUnableâ€ to Say Trump Didnâ€™t Commit Obstruction of Justice â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Comments TNS via ZUMA
The Mueller report is out. Hereâ€™s an excerpt from the executive summary of Volume II, which covers obstruction of justice on the part of President Trump:
[T]he actions we investigated can be divided into two phases, reflecting a possible shift in the Presidentâ€™s motives. The first phase covered the period from the Presidentâ€™s first interactions with Comey through the Presidentâ€™s firing of Comey. During that time, the President had been repeatedly told he was not personally under investigation.
Soon after the firing of Comey and the appointment of the Special Counsel, however, the President became aware that his own conduct was being investigated in an obstruction-of-justice inquiry. At that point, the President engaged in a second phase of conduct, involving public attacks on the investigation, non-public efforts to control it, and efforts in both public and private to encourage witnesses not to cooperate with the investigation.
â€¦.[I]f we had confidence after a thorough investigation of the facts that the President clearly did not commit obstruction of justice, we would so state. Based on the facts and the applicable legal standards, we are unable to reach that judgment.
There are only three short redactions in the executive summary of Volume II, and none in the section I quoted. The full report is here. Looking for news you can trust?

title: Mueller Found â€œCorrupt Intentâ€ Repeatedly in Donald Trumpâ€™s Actions Toward the Russia Investigation â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Mother Jones; James Berglie/ZUMA Press; Getty
In his report, Special Counsel Robert Mueller concludes that nothing in statute or the Constitution shields a president from obstruction-of-justice charges. Such charges, for example, wouldnâ€™t have a â€œchillingâ€ effect on a president because they requires a showing of corrupt motive, which â€œsets a demanding standard.â€ That standard rules out obstruction charges related to actions a president takes for political or policy reasons. â€œFor instance, the Presidentâ€™s decision to curtail a law-enforcement investigation to avoid international friction would not implicate the obstruction-of-justice statutes.â€
However, direct or indirect action to influence an investigation in order to avoid â€œpersonal embarrassment or legal liabilityâ€ for himself or his family would qualify as corrupt. With that in mind, hereâ€™s a selection of conclusions from the report about President Trumpâ€™s corrupt intent related to different aspects of the investigation. There are no redactions in the sections Iâ€™m quoting:
Firing of James Comey
Substantial evidence indicates that the catalyst for the Presidentâ€™s decision to fire Comey was Comeyâ€™s unwillingness to publicly state that the President was not personally under investigationâ€¦.Some evidence indicates that the President believed that the erroneous perception he was under investigation harmed his ability to manage domestic and foreign affairsâ€¦.Other evidence, however, indicates that the President wanted to protect himself from an investigation into his campaign â€¦.[T]he evidence does indicate that a thorough FBI investigation would uncover facts about the campaign and the President personally that the President could have understood to be crimes.
Attempt to fire the Special Counsel
Substantial evidence indicates that the Presidentâ€™s attempts to remove the Special Counsel were linked to the Special Counselâ€™s oversight of investigations that involved the Presidentâ€™s conduct â€”and most immediately, to reports that the President was being investigated for potential obstruction of justice.
Attempts to influence Jeff Sessions
Substantial evidence indicates that the Presidentâ€™s effort to have Sessions limit the scope of the Special Counselâ€™s investigation to future election interference was intended to prevent further investigative scrutiny of the Presidentâ€™s and his campaignâ€™s conduct â€¦.There is evidence that at least one purpose of the Presidentâ€™s conduct toward Sessions was to have Sessions assume control over the Russia investigation and supervise it in a way that would restrict its scopeâ€¦.A reasonable inference [â€¦] is that the President believed that an unrecused Attorney General would play a protective role and could shield the President from the ongoing Russia investigation.
Attempts to have Don McGahn fire the Special Counsel
Substantial evidence indicates that in repeatedly urging McGahn to dispute that he was ordered to have the Special Counsel terminated, the President acted for the purpose of influencing McGahnâ€™s account in order to deflect or prevent further scrutiny of the Presidentâ€™s conduct towards the investigation.
Trumpâ€™s actions related to Michael Cohen
In analyzing the Presidentâ€™s intent in his actions towards Cohen as a potential witness, there is evidence that could support the inference that the President intended to discourage Cohen from cooperating with the government because Cohenâ€™s information would shed adverse light on the Presidentâ€™s campaign-period conduct and statements.
Itâ€™s hard to read the report in its entirety without coming to the clear conclusion that Mueller believed Trump was guilty of obstruction of justice on many, many occasions. In multiple cases, all three parts of his three-part test are present: the obstructive acts are there, the â€œnexusâ€ to official proceedings is there, and corrupt intent is there.
However, he decided not to recommend charges because he knows the Attorney General disagrees with him about whether the law and the Constitution allow a sitting president to be indicted. Based on the evidence he lays out, this appears to be the sole reason he balked at recommending charges.Â¹ If this case had been about any other person on the planetâ€”or if the AG didnâ€™t have such strong protective instinctsâ€”Mueller would have recommended charges.
In the end, Mueller appears to have backed off because he didnâ€™t want to be involved in a big political fight. This does not speak very well for his willingness to do whatâ€™s right regardless of how it might affect him personally.
Â¹From the introduction to Volume II:
The Office of Legal Counsel (OLC) has issued an opinion finding that â€œthe indictment or criminal prosecution of a sitting President would impermissibly undermine the capacity of the executive branch to perform its constitutionally assigned functionsâ€ in violation of â€œthe constitutional separation of powers.â€ Given the role of the Special Counsel as an attorney in the Department of Justice and the framework of the Special Counsel regulation, see 28 U.S.C. Â§ 515; 28 C.F.R Â§ 600.7(a), this Office accepted OLCâ€™s legal conclusion for the purpose of exercising prosecutorial jurisdiction.

title: Itâ€™s Time to Start Ignoring Loudmouthed Assholes on Social Media â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Harvard postdoc Katie Bouman at the moment when the first image of a black hole was processed. MIT CSAIL
Brian Resnick writes about what happened after a picture of black-hole imager Katie Bouman went viral:
But then all the attention became a catalyst for an incredibly sexist backlash on social media and YouTube. It set off â€œwhat can only be described as a sexist scavenger hunt,â€ as The Verge described it, in which an apparently small group of vociferous men were questioning Boumanâ€™s role in the project. â€œPeople began going over her work to see how much sheâ€™d really contributed to the project that skyrocketed her to unasked-for fame.â€
There are two lessons here. First, the world is full of assholes. Second, we would all be better off if we ignored â€œsmall groups of vociferous menâ€ on social media. If they can manage to get some attention in real life, then fine. Maybe they should get some media coverage. But thereâ€™s no need to help them along the way. Looking for news you can trust?
