title: Inside Groundswell: Read the Memos of the New Right-Wing Strategy Group Planning a â€œ30 Front Warâ€ â€“ Mother Jones
content:
From left: Frank Gaffney; Ginni Thomas; Allen West
Believing they are losing the messaging war with progressives, a group of prominent conservatives in Washingtonâ€”including the wife of Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas and journalists from Breitbart News and the Washington Examinerâ€” has been meeting privately since early this year to concoct talking points, coordinate messaging, and hatch plans for â€œa 30 front war seeking to fundamentally transform the nation,â€ according to documents obtained by Mother Jones .
Dubbed Groundswell, this coalition convenes weekly in the offices of Judicial Watch, the conservative legal watchdog group. During these hush-hush sessions and through a Google group, the members of Groundswellâ€”including aides to congressional Republicansâ€”cook up battle plans for their ongoing fights against the Obama administration, congressional Democrats, progressive outfits, and the Republican establishment and â€œcluelessâ€ GOP congressional leaders. They devise strategies for killing immigration reform, hyping the Benghazi controversy, and countering the impression that the GOP exploits racism. And the Groundswell gang is mounting a behind-the-scenes organized effort to eradicate the outsize influence of GOP Ã¼ber-strategist/pundit Karl Rove within Republican and conservative ranks. (For more on Groundswellâ€™s â€œtwo front warâ€ against Roveâ€”a major clash on the rightâ€”click here .)
One of the influential conservatives guiding the group is Virginia â€œGinniâ€ Thomas, a columnist for the Daily Caller and a tea party consultant and lobbyist. Other Groundswell members include John Bolton, the former UN ambassador; Frank Gaffney, the president of the Center for Security Policy; Ken Blackwell and Jerry Boykin of the Family Research Council; Tom Fitton, the president of Judicial Watch; Gayle Trotter, a fellow at the Independent Womenâ€™s Forum; Catherine Engelbrecht and Anita MonCrief of True the Vote; Allen West, the former GOP House member; Sue Myrick, also a former House GOPer; Diana Banister of the influential Shirley and Banister PR firm ; and Max Pappas, a top aide to Sen. Ted Cruz (R-Texas).
Among the conveners listed in an invitation to a May 8 meeting of Groundswell were Stephen Bannon, executive chairman of Breitbart News Network; Dan Bongino, a former Secret Service agent who resoundingly lost a Maryland Senate race last year (and is now running for a House seat); Leonard Leo, executive vice president of the Federalist Society; Sandy Rios, a Fox News contributor; Lori Roman, a former executive director of the American Legislative Exchange Council; and Austin Ruse, the head of the Catholic Family and Human Rights Institute. Conservative journalists and commentators participating in Groundswell have included Breitbart News reporters Matthew Boyle and Mike Flynn, Washington Examiner executive editor Mark Tapscott, and National Review contributor Michael James Barton.
Meet the participants in Groundswell
Groundswell has collaborated with conservative GOPers on Capitol Hill, including Sens. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.) and Cruz and Rep. Jim Bridenstine (R-Okla.), a leading tea partier. At its weekly meetings, the group aims to strengthen the rightâ€™s messaging by crafting Twitter hashtags; plotting strategy on in-the-headlines issues such as voter ID, immigration reform, and the sequester; promoting politically useful scandals; and developing â€œaction items.â€
A certain amount of secrecy cloaks Groundswellâ€™s efforts. Though members have been encouraged to zap out tweets with a #GSW hashtag , a message circulated to members of its Google group noted that the role of certain advocates should be kept â€œoff of the Google group for OPSEC [operational security] reasons.â€ This â€œwill avoid any potential for bad press for someone if a communication item is leaked,â€ the message explained. (The Groundswell documents were provided to Mother Jones by a source who had access to its Google group page and who has asked not to be identified.)
â€œWe want to protect the strategic collaboration occurring at Groundswell and build on it. Please be careful about bringing guests and clear them ahead of time.â€ Washington is full of coalitions that meet to coordinate messaging and strategy. For two decades, conservative strategist Grover Norquist , who heads Americans for Tax Reform, has held his now-famous Wednesday morning meetings for a broad spectrum of Republicans, including conservatives opposed to gay rights and abortion rights and those who favor them, as well as GOPers on different sides of the immigration reform debate. Groundswell, which meets at the same time as Norquistâ€™s group, appears to be a more ideologically pure version of the Norquist confab, and its emergenceâ€”given the prominent role of Ginni Thomas and the participation of journalistsâ€”prompts several intriguing questions.
Critics have contended that Thomasâ€™ work as a lobbyist opposing Obamacare posed a conflict of interest for her husband, who would rule on the constitutionality of the health care reform initiative. (Clarence Thomas joined the Supreme Court minority that favored striking down the law.) And Common Cause has maintained that Justice Thomas had a conflict of interest when he participated in the Citizens United case because his wife at the time was running a conservative nonprofit fighting the â€œtyrannyâ€ of President Barack Obama that would benefit from removing limits on such groupsâ€™ spending and fundraising. With her involvement in Groundswellâ€”which zeroes in on contentious issues that come before the high court, including voting rights, abortion, and gay marriageâ€”Ginni Thomas continues to be intricately associated with matters on which her husband may have to render a decision. Ginni Thomas did not respond to requests for comment.
The participation of journalists in coordinating messaging with ideological advocates and political partisans raises another set of issues. Conservatives expressed outrage when news broke in 2009 about Journolist, a private email list where several hundred progressive-minded reporters, commentators, and academics exchanged ideas and sometimes bickered. (I was on Journolist, mainly as a lurker .) The late Andrew Breitbart once offered $100,000 for the full Journolist archives and denounced it as â€œthe epitome of progressive and liberal collusion that conservatives, Tea Partiers, moderates and many independents have long suspected and feared exists at the heart of contemporary American political journalism.â€ The Groundswell documents show conservative journalists, including several with Breitbart News , colluding on high-level messaging with leading partisans of the conservative movement.
How Groundswellers Win â€œBrownie Pointsâ€
Notes prepared after a Groundswell meeting held on March 27 detailed the groupâ€™s mission and origins :
Groundswell evolved out of conversations among conservative leaders after the November elections. This is the eighth meeting. Now others are asking to be included. Growth needs to be strategic; it should be made up of senior level people willing to collaborate. It is important to keep a balance of social conservatives, national security conservatives, and constitutional conservatives. Outreach has occurred to incorporate groups with extensive reach: Heritage, Heritage Action, FreedomWorks, AFP [Americans for Prosperity], FRC [Family Research Council] and the NRA, among othersâ€¦Our country is in peril. This is a critical moment needing critical leadership. We want to protect the strategic collaboration occurring at Groundswell and build on it. Please be careful about bringing guests and clear them ahead of time.
The memo declared that the goal was not to merely ponder, but to be proactive:
What Groundswell is not is a room of note takers. The goal of Groundswell is to sync messages and develop action from reports and information exchanged. Going forward there should be an action item accompanying each report.
At the March 27 meeting , Groundswell participants discussed one multipurpose theme they had been deploying for weeks to bash the president on a variety of fronts, including immigration reform and the sequester: Obama places â€œpolitics over public safety.â€ In a display of Groundswellâ€™s message-syncing, members of the group repeatedly flogged this phrase in public. Frank Gaffney penned a Washington Times op-ed titled â€œPutting Politics Over Public Safety.â€ Tom Fitton headlined a Judicial Watch weekly update â€œPolitics over Public Safety: More Illegal Alien Criminals Released by Obama Administration.â€ Peter List, editor of LaborUnionReport.com, authored a RedState.com post called â€œObamaâ€™s Machiavellian Sequestration Pain Game: Putting Politics Over Public Safety.â€ Matthew Boyle used the phrase in an immigration-related article for Breitbart . And Dan Bongino promoted Boyleâ€™s story on Twitter by tweeting , â€œPolitics over public safety?â€ In a message to Groundswellers, Ginni Thomas awarded â€œbrownie pointsâ€ to Fitton, Gaffney, and other members for promoting the â€œpolitics over public safetyâ€ riff.
â€œIf we lose on immigration, we lose on every other issue. They key to defeating this bill is Sen. Rubio.â€ There was much more on the agenda for the March 27 meeting than a single talking point. The group routinely addresses an ambitious to-do list for its campaign against the left. At that session, Groundswellers discussed several immigration-related â€œaction items.â€ These included attempting to link the pending reform bill to Obamacare and collecting health care reform horror stories to provide to Cruz, a leading opponent of the Senate immigration reform bill. (Cruz has repeatedly compared the legislation to the health care reform law.)
Groundswell members saw immigration as a life-or-death issue. â€œIf we lose on immigration,â€ the post-meeting memo noted, â€œwe lose on every other issue. The key to defeating this bill is Sen. Rubio. He can gracefully remove himself from the â€˜gang of 8â€™ and still save faceâ€¦The messaging on this issue has to be â€˜we canâ€™t trust Obamaâ€™ to enforce immigration laws after the amnesty.â€
The group also reviewed how best to oppose the confirmation of Tom Perez , Obamaâ€™s nominee for labor secretary. Groundswellers claimed that Perez, then a senior Justice Department official, supported â€œMuslim Brotherhood organizations and Shariah.â€ (One Groundswell memo maintained that Perez â€œis extremely antagonistic toward whites.â€) A third agenda item that Wednesday morning was beating back the effort to end the Boy Scouts of Americaâ€™s ban on gay Scouts. And there was yet another issue for the Groundswell members to stoke: â€œJohn Kerry has family ties to Iran that opens the doors to blackmail and other national security risks. Kerryâ€™s son in law is an Iranian American with extensive family still in Iran.â€ The post-meeting memo suggested Twitter hashtags to push: #CantTrustObama, #PoliticsOverPublicSafety, #SequesterLies.
â€œWeâ€™re Failing the Propaganda Battleâ€
The Groundswellers feel that they too often lose the political narrative to their progressive rivals. One memo that circulated among members declared, â€œWe must reclaim the language and put â€˜a faceâ€™ on our messages; tell stories. Write articles on 4th grade level!â€
A Groundswell memo noted, â€œTerms like, â€˜GOP,â€™ â€˜Tea Party,â€™ â€˜Conservativeâ€™ communicate â€˜racism.'â€ They proposed an alternative: â€œFredrick Douglas Republican.â€ Notes from a February 28 Groundswell gathering reflected both their collective sense of pessimism and desire for aggressive tactics: â€œWe are failing the propaganda battle with minorities. Terms like, â€˜GOP,â€™ â€˜Tea Party,â€™ â€˜Conservativeâ€™ communicate â€˜racism.'â€ The Groundswellers proposed an alternative: â€œFredrick Douglas Republican,â€ a phrase, the memo noted, that â€œchanges minds.â€ (His name is actually spelled â€œFrederick Douglass.â€) The meeting notes also stated that an â€œactive radical left is dedicated to destroy [sic] those who oppose themâ€ with â€œvicious and unprecedented tactics. We are in a real war; most conservatives are not prepared to fight.â€
The notes from the March 20 meeting summed up Groundswell griping: â€œConservatives are so busy dealing with issues like immigration, gay marriage and boy scouts there is little time left to focus on other issues. These are the very issues the Left wants to avoid but we need to magnify. Râ€™s cannot beat Obama at his own game but need to go on the offense and define the issues.â€ The groupâ€™s proposed offensive would include hyping the Fast and Furious gun-trafficking controversy, slamming Obamaâ€™s record, and touting Benghazi as a full-fledged scandal. â€œThe problem,â€ the memo noted, â€œis Speaker Boehner and [Rep.] Mike Rogers (Intelligence Community) are refusing to dealâ€ with the Benghazi issue. It added, â€œLeaders can and should be shamed into doing the right thing.â€
Another problem for right-wingers, this memo pointed out, was that though â€œa group of freshmen and sophomore representatives in Congressâ€¦are willing and ready to stand upâ€ for conservative causes, â€œno one is willing to step up and become that leader.â€ Reflecting the dim view held by Groundswell members of House GOPers, the memo maintained that too many Republican lawmakers were co-opted by power and reluctant to challenge House Republican leaders: â€œThe Speaker holds the control in the House. He controls committees, chairmanships, meeting rooms, etc. Conservatives sell out rationalizing their compromises will position them to advance their agenda through committee work. In reality they are being bought.â€ Boehner, according to his memo, was too frightened to confront Obama head-on regarding budget issues because he â€œbelieves that Newt lost his speakership due to the government shutdown.â€
Venting about weak and squishy GOP leaders was a regular feature of Groundswell gatherings. One action item put it bluntly :
GAP of REPUBLICAN LEADERSHIP: how do we tell them they are failing their base; will lose in 2014 unless they fight for principles (as opposed to show disdain for them and accommodate Obama; O is dividing Rs and they seem clueless: IDEAS NEEDED!
A week later, Newt Gingrich was scheduled to address the group on the â€œlack of Republican Leadership right now, and Rove.â€ For 10 minutes.
At the March 27 meeting, Groundswellers once more voiced their anger with the GOP establishment and Roveâ€”ideological sellouts, they believed, who undercut conservative candidates in order to back Republicans deemed more electable. They discussed the efforts among conservatives to respond to the Republican Partyâ€™s recently released autopsy (PDF) of the 2012 elections, which called on the party to be more inclusive of minorities and less severe on social issues.
Republican National Committee chairman Reince Priebus, the post-meeting memo huffed, â€œis sending messages to the partyâ€¦If we were all gay illegal aliens, the party likes us. He is preparing the way for a change on social issues by giving a warning, â€˜donâ€™t go Old Testamentâ€™ and advising the party to consider what Rove said about the next nominees could speak favorably of homosexual marriage in the campaign.â€ The memo summed up Groundswellâ€™s preferred solution to GOP woes: â€œembrace the libertarian and conservative wing of the party.â€
â€œIâ€™m Going to Need Help Pushing Backâ€
Shortly after its creation, Groundswell started bolstering interactions between right-wing advocates and conservative members of the Senate and the House. On March 5, Gaston Mooney, a staffer for the Senate Republican Steering Committee, posted a message to Groundswellâ€™s Google group asking for questions that could be posed to Gina McCarthy, Obamaâ€™s nominee to lead the EPA, during confirmation hearings or in meetings between her and individual senators. (She was confirmed as EPA chief this month.)
â€œIf we were all gay illegal aliens, the party likes us. [RNC chair Reince Priebus] is preparing the way for a change on social issues by giving a warning, â€˜donâ€™t go Old Testament.'â€ At an April 3 meeting , Groundswell members were encouraged to send Paul Teller, executive director of the Republican Study Committee, the caucus of House conservatives, â€œfeasible asks in exchange for raised debt ceiling.â€ The post-meeting memo noted, â€œHouse conservatives want clear consensus on what the conservative grassroots want to see negotiated.â€ Here was a chance for Groundswellers to shape the next debt ceiling showdown.
In Groundswellâ€™s first months, one of the most active members in its Google group was Danielle Cutrona, chief counsel to Alabama Sen. Jeff Sessions. She frequently placed informationâ€”speeches, articles, press releasesâ€”on Groundswellâ€™s Google group. In February, she posted opposition research material regarding a judicial appointment and asked members to distribute it: â€œAny help is much appreciated.â€ In another message to Groundswell, she requested assistance in opposing the pro-immigration reform GOP establishment. â€œIâ€™m going to need help pushing back,â€ she wrote.
On one occasion , Cutrona promoted a column from the conservative site RedState.com . Headlined â€œWho is Going to Put an End to the McCain/Graham Circus?â€ this RedState.com post excoriated Republican Sens. John McCain and Lindsey Graham as â€œBenedict Arnoldsâ€ for retreating on their opposition to Chuck Hagelâ€™s nomination as defense secretary and for â€œtheir treachery on the issue of illegal immigration.â€ Cutrona, who occasionally used her official Senate email to communicate with Groundswell members, was encouraging this band of conservatives to spread the word that two party colleagues of her boss were ideological traitors. A spokesman for Sessions says that this blog post did not reflect Cutronaâ€™s views and â€œwas simply one of scores of diverse news and opinion pieces she emailed on immigration.â€
â€œEven If the Idea Isnâ€™t Perfect, I Can Help Massage Itâ€
Several conservative journalists have enthusiastically participated in Groundswellâ€™s deliberations. In March, Mark Tapscott, the executive editor of the conservative Washington Examiner , sent his most recent column to group members . It focused on a theme that Groundswellers had resolved to hype: President Obama is a divider. And after a meeting that month, Tapscott wrote to the group , â€œEnjoyed hearing from all of you who spoke earlier today. Itâ€™s amazing how much we are accomplishing on so many fronts.â€ But Tapscott tells Mother Jones that after attending one or two meetings at the invitation of Ginni Thomas, he decided to stop participating: â€œThe implication of attending is that youâ€™re participating in their planning, and, as a journalist, I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s appropriate. Other journalists may think differently.â€
At another Groundswell gathering, according to the minutes , the members decided to ask Breitbart â€˜s Stephen Bannon to arrange for his media organization â€œto get senators on the record regarding their support [or non-support]â€ of the filibuster that GOP Sens. Mike Lee, Rand Paul, and Ted Cruz were threatening to mount against the gun control bill. This suggested that the Groundswellers thought they could task Breitbart News to pursue a story that would be strategically useful for the group. ( Breitbart News was already covering the possible filibuster.)
â€œItâ€™s amazing how much we are accomplishing on so many fronts,â€ the Washington Examiner â€˜s Mark Tapscott wrote to fellow Groundswell members. Groundswell has forged a particularly close relationship with Breitbart . Matthew Boyle, one of Breitbart â€˜s more prominent reporters, has attended Groundswell meetings, used the group as a source for tips and a mechanism to promote his stories, and joined in its efforts to whip up coordinated bullet points to be deployed by conservative advocacy shops. In February, he tried to enlist the group to push a story he had written the year before at the Daily Caller , in which he maintained the Justice Department was in cahoots with the liberal group Media Matters to smear conservative whistleblowers and journalists. In a long note addressed to all Groundswellersâ€”written at a time when reporter Bob Woodward was making (what turned out to be inflated) claims about the Obama White House intimidating foesâ€”Boyle said, â€œFigured this might be a good time to bring this story back up and see if thereâ€™s a way to drive it.â€
Boyle said he was hoping to prompt congressional Republicans to launch an investigation. He contended he had only revealed the â€œtip of the icebergâ€ and shared his suspicion that many government agencies (State, the CIA, the Pentagon, the EPA, and more) were conspiring with â€œfar left wing groupsâ€ to undermine conservatives in the media: â€œI think we can get at the heart of the Obama adminâ€™s weaknesses here.â€ He explained: â€œAny evidence obtained would be more proof of collusion between the administration and the media and far left groups, while at the same time serving as evidence of whatever ridiculously moronic big government policies theyâ€™re pushing are.â€
The following month, Boyle sent a message to Groundswell members seeking tips and offering to help shape stories Groundswellers wanted to disseminate: â€œIâ€™m saying we can get pieces out fast on Breitbart. Whenever you have an idea, email or call me with a pitch and Iâ€™ll do my best to get the story out there. Keep us on offense, them on defense. Even if the idea isnâ€™t perfect, I can help massage it to get there.â€
A high-priority cause for Groundswellers is voter identification effortsâ€”what progressives would call voter suppressionâ€”and when Groundswellers developed a thread on their Google group page exploring the best way to pitch the rightâ€™s voter identification endeavors as a major voting rights case was pending in the Supreme Court, the coalitionâ€™s friendly journalists joined right in. Dan Bongino, the ex-Secret Service agent and 2012 Senate candidate, kicked off the discussion : â€œWe need to reframe this. This narrative of the Left has already taken hold in MD. The words â€˜Voter IDâ€™ are already lost & equated with racism. Maybe a â€˜free and fair elections initiativeâ€™ with a heavy emphasis on avoiding ANY voter disenfranchisement combined with an identification requirement which includes a broader range of documents.â€
Sheryl Kaufman, communications director for Rep. Jim Bridenstine, chimed in: â€œâ€˜OBAMAGRATIONâ€™â€”I love it!! Communicates the similarity with Obamacare.â€ In response, Tapscott suggested, â€œHow about â€˜Election Integrityâ€™?â€ And Gaffney weighed in: â€œI like it.â€ Fitton noted that Judicial Watch had an â€œElection Integrity Project.â€ Boyle proposed, â€œFair and equal elections,â€ explaining, â€œTerms â€˜fairâ€™ and â€˜equalâ€™ connect with most people. Itâ€™s why the left uses them.â€ Then came True the Voteâ€™s Anita MonCrief: â€œWe do a lot under the Election Integrity Banner. Does not resonate with the people. Voter Rights may be better. We really have been trying to get the messaging right.â€
Minutes later, Breitbart â€˜s Mike Flynn tried to change the conversation , noting that Boyle earlier in the week had reported that Obamaâ€™s daughters had been vacationing in the Bahamas while the White House had suspended tours due to the sequester. â€œThe Obama White House has never been so exposed to public criticism as they are right now, because of their decision to cancel WH tours,â€ Flynn wrote. â€œEverything should be focused on that front.â€ He declared, â€œWe have to be willing to march to the sound of the guns.â€ (Earlier in the week, Boyle had posted his story on the Obama daughters on Groundswellâ€™s Google group page, noting, â€œI think this fits in nicely with that politics over public safety themeâ€¦Enjoy.â€) Ignoring Flynnâ€™s missive, Engelbrecht, the president of True the Vote, wrote, â€œWe bill ourselves as an Election Integrity Initiative and have found it strikes the right tone.â€
In a response to a request for comment regarding his participation in Groundswellâ€™s message-making, Flynn emailed, â€œWe have reporters covering lots of meetings in DC, as Iâ€™m sure you do as well. As you know, it provides critical background to know whatâ€™s happening on the Hill.â€ In a subsequent email, Flynn insisted, â€œ[N]either Boyle nor I have spent 1 minute on any messaging. We havenâ€™t spent any time creating talking points.â€ Flynn added, â€œ[W]e are journalists with a point of view. We are open about that. We attend meetings of conservatives. Where we are allowed, we attend meetings of leftist activists.â€ Boyle did not respond to requests for comment.
â€œWe All Lament the Difficulty We Have Persuading Americansâ€
In between the weekly meetings, Groundswellers keep on scheming, frequently using their Google group to share ideas and need-to-know information. The material is often routine: a John Bolton op-ed , a press release opposing the nomination of the EPA administrator, a call to rally support for a Rand Paul filibuster. Often the material reveals the groupâ€™s ideological excesses, such as a PowerPoint supposedly proving that John Brennan, the Obama national security adviser who has become CIA chief, is soft on radical Islam. In one post, Ginni Thomas encouraged Groundswell members to watch Agenda: Grinding America Down , a documentary that claims that progressives (including Obama) seek â€œa brave new worldâ€ based on the â€œfailed policies and ideologies of communismâ€ and that an evil left is purposefully â€œdestroying the greatest country in all of world history.â€ MonCrief posted an email noting that the bombs that exploded at the Boston Marathon were â€œsimilar to Bill Ayersâ€™ Weather Underground nail bomb.â€
But Groundswellers constantly brainstorm via their Google group in search of a magic talking point, or a silver bullet of messaging. On April 24, Keli Carender, the national grassroots coordinator of Tea Party Patriots, posted a message to the Google group, writing, â€œWe should have a unified name for the immigration bill so that as the other side is calling it â€˜reform,â€™ we present a unified front against that notion. If weâ€™re all calling it different things, their â€˜reformâ€™ message will win. We only combat the idea that it is reform if we hammer back with one different phrase/name.â€ She tossed out a few ideas: â€œSchumer-Rubio bill,â€ â€œanti-security bill,â€ and â€œamnesty bill.â€ Sheryl Kaufman, the communications director for Rep. Jim Bridenstine, chimed in that she was fond of a phrase derived by MonCreif: â€œâ€˜OBAMAGRATIONâ€™â€”I love it!! Communicates the similarity with Obamacare.â€
When Campaign for Americaâ€™s Future, a progressive group, sent out an email regarding the sequester headlined â€œDonâ€™t let Republicans destroy the economy,â€ Carender sent a message to Groundswell members via the Google group: â€œWhat about a â€˜stick with sequesterâ€™ (or similar) mantra from our side?â€ Responding to Carenderâ€™s note, Peter List of LaborUnionReport.com wrote, â€œMost Americans donâ€™t understand sequesters. We need to be more clever than the Left on thisâ€¦Something amusing and easy for LIVs [low-information voters] to understand. Maybe a tie in to Humpty Dumpty (the economy) and all King Obamaâ€™s men (â€˜tax increasesâ€™) not being able to put Humpty Dumpty back together again. (Iâ€™m open to anythingâ€¦and just made that up.)â€
At another point, List emailed Ginni Thomas an idea for an anti-Obama ad that he thought could go viral:
A 15 sec internet [YouTube ad] featuring ethnically diverse children on a merry-go-round [soft music]â€¦
Nuclear explosion.
Two bullet points on the facts.
Call to action:
Tell President Obama & Congress not to cut our nationâ€™s defense.
Thomas posted the note for all in Groundswell to see. â€œBrilliant idea,â€ she commented. â€œâ€¦Taker?â€
Several months after Groundswell kicked off, Steven Sutton, vice president of development for the conservative Leadership Institute and a former chief of staff to several House GOPers, proposed a â€œstrategic message development projectâ€ for the outfit. â€œWhat is needed,â€ he wrote , â€œis an umbrella thematic message under which each specific issue can be magnified and maximized. For those familiar with it, this is an extension and development of the Leesburg Grid (which the Left has co-opted and now uses extensively, and the Right has ignored and allowed to fall into disuse.)â€
Sutton suggested using four main themes: Obama and liberal policies fail; Obama and liberal policies make things worse; there is a lack of leadership in the White House; and Obama â€œputs politics ahead of people/our country/America.â€ These themes, he contended, â€œare best used sequentially, rather than randomly/haphazardly/isolatedâ€¦The most important thing is to think thematically and drive these messages.â€ Sutton went on:
Issues matter. Details matter. Substance matters. But theme matters more. Substance matters only as it helps to reinforce the themes.
We all lament the difficulty we have persuading Americans. After all, we have the facts, figures, and data to prove our points. Why canâ€™t we persuade? There are many tactics we can use to help persuade (telling stories, finding victims, tempering tone). But these tactics pale in comparison to the importance of providing a contextâ€¦a themeâ€¦to help people organize their thoughts and opinions.
Groundswell has set itself up as the theme lab for the true-red activists of the conservative movement. Fearing that some hydra of the left has long been running wild, vanquishing the right, and bringing the nation closer to utter ruin, the members of Groundswell have birthed a hydra of their own.
Additional reporting by Kate Sheppard .

title: Religion and Racism Still Go Hand-in-Hand In the GOP â€“ Mother Jones
content:
Ross Douthat uses a new study from the Voter Study Group to defend religious Republicans:
In general, churchgoing Republicans look more like the party many elite conservatives wanted to believe existed before Trump came along â€” more racially-tolerant, more accepting of multiculturalism and globalization, and also more consistently libertarian on economics. Secularized Trump voters look more like the party as Trump has tried to remake it, blending an inchoate economic populism with strong racial resentments.
The problem is that the word â€œchurchgoingâ€ is doing a lot of heavy lifting here. How about if instead we just take a straight look at how religious people say they are? To do that, we have to read a report by the same author for the same group published a year ago, which identifies a group called â€œAmerican Preservationistsâ€ as Trumpâ€™s core constituency. Here it is:
Despite being the most likely group to say that religion is â€œvery importantâ€ to them, they are the least likely to attend church regularly â€¦.They are far more likely to have a strong sense of their own racial identity and to say their Christian identity is very important to themâ€¦.They feel the greatest amount of angst over race relations: they believe that anti-white discrimination is as pervasive as other forms of discrimination, and they have cooler feelings (as measured on a feeling thermometer scale) toward minorities. They agree in overwhelming numbers that real Americans need to have been born in America or have lived here most of their lives and be Christian.
Unsurprisingly, it turns out that Trumpâ€™s core supporters are the most religious and feel the greatest amount of racial resentment. However, they donâ€™t actually attend church a lot.
So hereâ€™s the dodge. Nearly every survey suggests that Trumpâ€™s most loyal Evangelical voters are also the most racist and xenophobic. But if you donâ€™t like that conclusion, you can instead look at â€œchurchgoing,â€ and youâ€™ll find that itâ€™s weak churchgoers who are the most racist and xenophobic. Then itâ€™s a quick hop and a skip from â€œnon-churchgoingâ€ to â€œsecularâ€ and youâ€™re all done. Religious Trump supporters are great! Itâ€™s the secular ones who are the real problem.
But itâ€™s all sleight of hand. Religion goes together with both national and racial identity and it always has. Trumpâ€™s most religious supporters may, like him, not actually show up for church services very often, but theyâ€™re still the most religious wing of the Republican Party. Theyâ€™re also the most racist wing. You might try to camouflage this with irrelevant statistics, but thereâ€™s really no way of getting around it.
